docs.lead_paragraph: A judge affirmed that the government must distribute an AIDS drug at public hospitals that have adequate staff and expertise while it appeals a court ruling that it make the drug available. The decision upheld an order from two weeks ago when the government was told to hand out nevirapine while it appealed the original ruling, made in December. The government has argued that the drug, which is already being distributed in a pilot program, needs to be tested more thoroughly before it is widely distributed. Nevirapine reduces the risk of transmission of H.I.V. from pregnant mothers to their unborn babies. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Government Must Offer AIDS Drug

docs.abstract: South African judge affirms government most distribute AIDS drug nevirapine at public hospitals while it appeals ruling that it make drug available; drug cuts risk of transmission of HIV from pregnant mothers to their unborn babies (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors in the New York area face sharp increases in their medical malpractice insurance costs, which are already among the highest in the country. Insurance rate increases, most of them ranging from 10 to 40 percent, are already taking effect in New Jersey and Connecticut. In New York State, a majority of doctors are likely to pay at least 20 percent more in premiums over the next year. Those premiums are already substantial; for obstetricians and neurosurgeons, they can run to more than $100,000 annually.

headline.main: Doctors Face A Big Jump In Insurance
